description: From Middle English curteyn, corteyn, cortyn, cortine, from Old French cortine, from Medieval Latin cōrtīna (“curtain”), from Latin cohors (“court, enclosure”).

entries.meaning: A piece of cloth covering a window, bed, etc. to offer privacy and keep out light.
examples: Thus the red damask curtains which now shut out the fog-laden, drizzling atmosphere of the Marylebone Road, had cost a mere song, and yet they might have been warranted to last another thirty years. A great bargain also had been the excellent Axminster carpet which covered the floor; as, again, the arm-chair in which Bunting now sat forward, staring into the dull, small fire.

entries.meaning: A similar piece of cloth that separates the audience and the stage in a theater.
(theater, by extension) The beginning of a show; the moment the curtain rises.
examples: He took so long to shave his head that we arrived 45 minutes after curtain and were denied late entry.

entries.meaning: (fortifications) The flat area of wall which connects two bastions or towers; the main area of a fortified wall.
examples: Captain Rense, beleagring the Citie of Errona for us, […] caused a forcible mine to be wrought under a great curtine of the walles […].

entries.meaning: (euphemistic, also "final curtain", sometimes in the plural) Death.
examples: For life is quite absurd / And death's the final word / You must always face the curtain with a bow.

entries.meaning: (architecture) That part of a wall of a building which is between two pavilions, towers, etc.

verbs.description: curtain (third-person singular simple present curtains, present participle curtaining, simple past and past participle curtained)

entries.meaning: To cover (a window) with a curtain; to hang curtains.
examples: The window, softly curtained with dotted swiss, became the focus of my desperate hour-by-hour attention.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) To hide, cover or separate as if by a curtain.
